Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Understanding of role of journalism
I learned a lot of thinking and tools necessary for investigative journalism

As per the name of the course, the knowledge, skills, and insights that I developed while taking the Investigative Journalism class relate to investigative journalism. But jokes aside, it's surprising how much I learned from this class in the five weeks I attended it. I learned the history of investigative journalism which begins with Benjamin Bache covering a expose about George Washington's lavish spending, I learn about the importance to write every day to increase your ability in the craft, I learned about public documents and how regular citizens have the right to access these public documents (Which is perhaps different in Indonesia, I have to check), how we can learn about a person's entire life just by viewing their public documents, and many more pertaining to the craft and ethics of the journalistic occupation.
Journalism writing and housing policies in New Haven
being a journalist is not only about gathering information, but also empathize with the human sources and interviewee, keeping our ethics, and try to find a way not to hurt people with our writing.

Seems endless, but most notably: how to interview people (with power or without power), how to utilize public records and/or documents on investigation, how to write a interview report and make a good lede.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Very interactive
Great prof

Strength:
- Very experiential, students learn journalism by actually doing some journalistic work in real life.
- The lectures are some of the best and most insightful: the lecturer is very charismatic which increases the engagement of the subject.
- Most of the tips and insights given by the lecturer is very relevant to the subject and to the craft of writing in general which further drives its engagement.
- The lectures can be entertaining at times.

Weaknesses:
- Sometimes the lecturer (Mr. Bruce Shapiro) looks tired and ends the class an hour early.
- Some of the tasks are vague since the syllabus has more of a loose structure to it.
- Sometimes the lecturer forgot to put the forum discussions every week.
- The lecturer has yet to post his presentations anywhere.
- Sometimes the reading can be heavy without much time to read it all.
- It can be intimidating to speak up since everyone there is smart lmao.
Strength is the big project of this course, the weakness is the strict time of the project.
i love this class is filled with amazing student and led by and amazing professor. even though sometimes I'm having a hard time to keep up with the assignments, I still found it interesting.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes!
if they are interested in investigative journalism, yes
Of course. Especially students who are interested in history, law, pursuing a career in journalism, or the craft of writing in general. The syllabus accounts for all these avenues of interest.
Yes. Because it tells Yale students who you could be in the future.

yes. the way Professor Shapiro explains things is so interesting and far from boring. the assignments might be confusing for the first time, but when you find ut what is is actually about, you will amazed by the result,

YES. This course is super hands-on, it will urge you to explore, to collaborate, and provide you with practical insights on investigative journalism. The class is structured as a "news room" so you can imagine how great the conversations are.

narratives.question_text: How will you use the knowledge and skills you learned in this course in your future endeavors?
comments: While I do not plan to be a journalist, I will certainly be using the writing skills, evidence-based inquiry techniques, and interviewing advice that we learned during this course.
I will use the writing and interviewing skills likely in a non-journalism field but it will be very helpful.

I plan to use my knowledge and skills learned from this course to advance my craft in writing which I plan to pursue in the future. And perhaps create my own journalistic organization at my university where I can give light on some issues in my community or the institution that is often overlooked.
Journalism writing
i will try to use the skills I learned from this class to help me navigate my undergraduate thesis. How we collected information and approached human sources was very beneficial even in daily life.

The practical knowledge that I learned will help me on my future projects on journalism and beyond. It provided me with more context to approach human subjects and interlocutors. Honestly, it also makes me want to apply for a journalism degree for my masters.
